headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
Welcome to the TSMC second quarter 2010 results webcast conference call. This conference call is being webcast live via the TSMC website at www.tsmc.com and only in audio mode. Your dial-in lines are also in listen-only mode.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Dr. Elizabeth Sun, TSMC Head of Investor Relations.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Leticia. Good morning and good evening everyone, welcome to TSMC’s second quarter 2010 conference call. Joining us on the call are Dr. Morris Chang, our Chairman and CEO and Ms. Lora Ho, our Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
The format for today’s conference call will be as follows. First, Lora will summarize our operations in the second quarter and give you our guidance for the third quarter. Afterwards, TSMC’s Chairman, Dr. Chang will provide his general remark on the business outlook and a couple of key messages. Then we will open the floor to questions.
For those participants who do not yet have a copy of the press release, you may download it from TSMC’s Website at www.tsmc.com. Please also download the summary slides in relation to today’s quarterly review presentation.
I would like to remind all listeners that following discussions may contain forward-looking statements that are subject to significant risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements.
Information as to those factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from TSMC’s forward-looking statements may be found in TSMC’s annual report on Form 20-F filed with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission on April 15, 2010, and such other documents as TSMC may file with or submit to the SEC from time to time. Except as required by law, we undertake no obligation to update any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
Now, I’d like to turn the call over to Lora.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Elizabeth. Good morning and good evening to everyone. Welcome to our second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. I will start today’s conference call with a highlight of the second quarter, then I will give you the outlook of our third quarter. Please refer to the quarterly financial summary slides on our Website. All dollar figures are in NT dollars, unless otherwise stated.
Customers’ demands for TSMC wafers continued to be robust in the second quarter, which translated to revenue and shipment growth across all major segments, technologies and geographic areas.
Net sales reached NT$105 million, up 13.9% from the first quarter and up 41.4% from the year ago quarter. Wafer shipments were at NT$2.93 million 8-inch equivalent wafers increased 14.9% from the prior quarter and 48.5% on the same quarter last year.
Gross margin was 49.5%, representing a 1.6 percentage point increase from the first quarter and a 3.3 percentage increase from a second quarter level.
Operating margin of 38.6% was also up 1.6 percentage points sequentially, and up 4.7 percentage points compared with second quarter ‘09. EPS for the second quarter 2010 reached NT$1.55. ROE was 31.6%.
Now let’s take a look at income statement. Second quarter gross margin was 49.5% up by 1.6 percentage point from 47.9% in the first quarter. The increase was mainly due to a higher capacity utilization rate and a continued cost improvement, partially offset by an adverse inventory valuation adjustment and an increase in raw material costs.
Operating expenses increased NT$1.4 billion from the first quarter as we accelerated the development for the most advanced technologies and expanded business scale and activities to support future growth.
Non-operating income increased by NT$450 million from first quarter primarily due to the higher disposal gain from financial assets and the absence of earthquake scrap loss in first quarter.
Net investment gain was NT$529 million up NT$352 million from the prior quarter, mostly due to the business improvement among certain invested companies. Net margin was 38.4%, up 1.9 percentage points sequentially and up 5.5 percentage point year-over-year.
On page six, let’s now turn to revenue analysis. Revenue from all major segments increased sequentially. Consumer was the strongest with 26% sequential growth. Communication, Computer and Industrial applications grew 22%, 1% and 14% respectively.
Overall, revenue from Communications, Computer, Consumer and Industrial applications accounted for 41%, 29%, 15% and 15% respectively of our wafer sales in second quarter ‘10.
Trends in Consumer demand was also seen across all technologies. Rapid ramping of 40-nanometer continued to lead growth and it reached 16% of total wafer revenue in the second quarter.
The revenue mix of 65-nanometer and 90-nanometer remained stable at 27% and 16% of total wafer sales respectively. Revenue from 0.13-micron and below represented 72% of total wafer sales for this quarter.
Now, let’s move on to the balance sheet and cash flow statement. We ended the second quarter with NT$207 billion in cash and short-term investments, representing an increase of NT$15 billion from the first quarter.
Total current liabilities increased by NT$88 billion, primarily due to the increase in cash dividends payable and an increase in short-term loans.
Accounts receivable days were 39 days. Inventory turnover days stayed flat at 45 days. Net fixed asset turnover was 1.3 times.
Cash generated from operating activities totaled NT$49 billion, representing an increase of $3 billion from the prior quarter, mainly due to the increase in net income.
Capital expenditure was NT$53 billion in the second quarter. Meanwhile, we borrowed NT$18 billion in short-term loans. The purpose was to hedge a portion of our net position in the U.S. dollars.
Meanwhile, during the second quarter we also invested NT$1.6 billion or 21% ownership of Stion, a U.S. based solar company.
In sum, the ending cash balance was NT$172 billion, increased NT$12.7 billion sequentially. Free cash flow was a net outflow of NT$3.8 billion.
Now let’s turn to capacity and capital expenditure. For the full year 2010 in order to meet continuing strong demand for TSMC’s advanced technologies, we have accelerated our capacity expansion plan.
Under the current plan, overall capacity is expected to increase by 14% year-over-year compared with a 13% increase planned in the last quarter. 12-inch wafer capacity is expected to increase by 36% in 2010 under the current plan.
The total installed capacity was about 2.75 million wafers in the second quarter, representing a 7.1% increase from the prior quarter. We expect the capacity will continue to increase in third quarter by around 7% and further into the fourth quarter by around 3.5%.
In terms of capital expenditure, we spent $1.66 billion in the second quarter. Total capital expenditure in the first half of 2010 was $3.1 billion.
Now, let’s turn to the outlook for the third quarter of 2010. Based on the current business expectations and a forecast exchange rate of NT$31.87, we expect our consolidated revenue in third quarter to come in between NT$109 billion and NT$111 billion.
In terms of margins, we expect our third quarter growth margin to be between 48% and 50%., operating margin to be between 36% and 38%.
This concludes my remark today. Now, I will turn the call over to Dr. Morris Chang, our Chairman and CEO for his remarks.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
Hi everybody, I’d like to make a few comments on market outlook and then supply chain inventory, and then our technology and our payback and capacity plan, and finally a few comments about our new businesses.
First off, on market outlook; our 2010 annual growth forecast for the end semiconductor system markets remain essentially unchanged.
PC, we predict will be 17% year-over-year growth this year. Handsets, we predict will be about 13% year-over-year growth, and digital consumer electronics we predict will be 8% year-over-year, and that’s one point higher than we predicted earlier.
Now, on the semiconductor market, our forecast now is 30% growth this year, and that’s an upward revision from 22% that we made in April. The upward revision is, primarily due to our reassessment of the strength of inventory restocking in the semiconductor supply chain. At the same time, we also forecast that the 2010 foundry market will grow by about 40%, and that’s up from the 36% we forecasted in April.
Now, a few comments about supply chain inventories. Regarding supply chain inventories, based on the second quarter results reported so far, inventory dollar and BOI at most reported IC and the system companies have increased from first quarter.
We estimate that supply chain inventories in aggregate are still below seasonal levels at the end of second quarter, and in fact will still be below seasonal levels at the end of third quarter.
For fabless and IBM companies reported so far, inventory levels have increased at a rate close to the increase in sales. Aggregate BOI increased marginally, but are still lower than seasonal for second quarter.
We expect that chip companies’ inventory levels and BOI will increase slowly and reach close to seasonal levels by fourth quarter. In other words, the chip companies’ inventories run pretty much parallel to the supply chain inventories, perhaps a little better. They were lower than the total supply chain inventories.
Now on technology, TSMC’s 40-nanometer technology is progressing well. It has already accounted for 16% of our total wafer revenues in the second quarter with gross margins in the mid-40s.
We expect the margins of the 40-nanometer technology to further improve and we’ll be very close to the corporate overall level by fourth quarter this year.
On 28-nanometers, our offerings are rich. We have three high-k metal gate processes and one conventional silicon oxynitride process, covering a full range of solutions for customers from high performance to low power to cost-sensitive applications.
We have 28HP, which is high performance, high-k metal gate or high speed ASICs and multi-gigahertz processors. We have 28 HPM, which is the best high-k metal gate SoC technology with broadest range in speed, leakage best suited for smartbooks and other mobile Internet devices.
We have 28HPL, which is lowest standing-by power high-k metal gate technology for mobile and the consumer application. Then we have 28LP, which is low cost conventional CMOS for smartphones and consumer applications.
In the foundry market, we believe that we have the best 28-nanometer, high high-k metal gate SRAM yield and performance while providing two times gate density improvement over our industry leading 40-nanometer technology. Based on public data, TSMC’s gate-last process outperforms competitions gate-first process by a good margin in both the low power and to the high performance classes.
On 20-nanometer developments, we expect to roll out TSMC’s 20-nanometer technology in the second half of 2012.
Our 20-nanometer process will use planar bulk transistors not SOI, coupled with a 20-nanometer not 22-nanometer solution. It offers best value per cost for our customers.
Our 20-nanometers we have two times gate density over our 28-nanometers, with innovations in both immersion lithography and mobility enhancement techniques. TSMC’s 20-nanometer technology is expected to deliver better performance and produce savings on intrinsic wafer cost.
Other than the Moore’s Law progression, which I have talked about, we have spend a great deal of efforts in developing specialty technologies to capture the market trend of integrating more specialty features with CMOS logic and the trend of continually scaling down the geometries for cost and form factor advantages.
Our technology leadership in these specialty technologies improved both feature improvement and the ability to further shrink the geometries. We have already achieved some of very good results. For example, for automotive, we currently use 65-nanometer and 90-nanometer to deliver engine control processors.
For CMOS image sensors, we use 65-nanometer and backside illumination to achieve the best quantum efficiency. For embedded DRAM, we use 40-nanometers to deliver the fastest network processors. For embedded Flash we use 0.11-micron to enable ultra low leakage MCU, microcontroller units of one picoAmp per micron.
For MEMS, we use 0.18-micron to compete 3D CMOS MEMS integration. For power ICs, we use 0.18-micron to achieve the lowest turn-on resistance in the industry.
Our technology efforts including both Moore’s Laws progression and the More Than Moore technologies have attracted many customers to expand their engagement with TSMC.
I mentioned last time that our sales in China has overtaken our sales in Japan, but that was only true for last year. Now this year because of the expanded customer engagement we have in Japan, Japan sales are again raising ahead of Mainland China’s. Of course, Mainland China sales continue to grow at a very high rate, but we believe that Japan will also grow at a very high rate in the coming years.
Now, a few comments on our capacity plan. TSMC’s business model is very importantly partnership with our customers. In fact, virtually all of our major customers are our partners, and all important semiconductor houses are our major customers. We have a responsibility to them to do our utmost to respond to their demand.
Our customers demand for this year and their forecast demand for 2011have both risen since January. Therefore, we have also accelerated our capital spending.
We now forecast our 2010 capital expenditure for the foundry business to be approximately NT$5.8 billion and capital spending for new business to be approximately NT$100 million. Therefore, our total capital expenditure for 2010 is forecast to be approximately NT$5.9 billion.
I want to emphasize that TSMC builds capacity to customer’s demand. We do not build capacity on speculation. In other words, we don’t first build capacity and then look for customer’s businesses.
A major part of the capital spending this year is to ramp-up two of our existing 12-inch GigaFabs, Fab 12 Phase 5 and Fab 14 Phase 4. Each GigaFab when fully loaded has a monthly capacity of around 150,000 12-inch wafers which is three to four times the size of a regular wafer Fab.
Two weeks ago, we also broke ground for our third 12-inch GigaFabs. We call it Fab 15. It is in the Taichung Science Park. We expect to complete Fab construction by early next year and begin installing tools shortly after that.
We have also experienced, accelerated our sourcing by IBMs and growing presence of fabless customers in specialty technologies, such as CMOS image sensors, embedded memories, high voltage, automotive and power.
Therefore, a part of the capital spending will include capacity support for these More Than Moore special technologies. We will support these technologies with both 8-inch and 12-inch capacities in the next few years.
Let me give you a more detailed breakdown of this year’s capital spending for our foundry business, spending for capacity for 28-nanometer, 40-nanometer, and 65-nanometer technologies accounts for 79%; spending for capacity for More Than Moore technologies accounts for 13%; spending for tools and equipment for R&D accounts for 8%.
Now, we increased our capital expenditure forecast from NT$4.8 billion that we gave in January to NT$5.9 billion now. Among the NT$1.1 billion increase in CapEx, the breakdown is as follows, 20 and 28-nanometer capacity spending increased by about NT$315 million; 65-nanometer capacity spending increased by about NT$450 million; specialty technology spending increased by close to $300 million.
Now, I’d like to turn to new businesses. I want to make some remarks on TSMC’s initiatives in the solar and LED lighting market. As you may know, both markets have been growing fast and will continue their growth pattern for a long time due to their long-term economic values as well as the sustainable environmental benefits. However, technology advances together with efficient and large scale manufacturing are essential to reap those benefits.
Emerging these markets, TSMC aims to differentiate ourselves in technology and manufacturing as we have successfully done in the Silicon IC industry.
On the solar front, TSMC have made significant moves during the last year to ensure ourselves a competitive technology and accelerate our entry to the market.
Through the recent technology license and the investment agreement with Stion Corporation, we are transferring and developing together high conversion efficiency CIGS thin-film technology with a very low intrinsic cost structure, based on which both companies will aggressively build our manufacturing capacity to scale in the near future.
We strongly believe that CIGS technology will provide a long-term competitive solution to this high growth market. Earlier, strategic investment in Motech, which is a major crystalline silicon solar photovoltaic manufacturer has accelerated our learning curve and their solar cell support will enable our early entry in the solar market.
As to the LED lighting area, we’re establishing our proprietary capabilities utilizing TSMC’s own technology expertise in semiconductor processing and silicon-based packaging techniques. These intensive technology development activities are progressing well.
While our first LED lighting plant, broken ground in March, is expected to have equipment moving later in the year. In the meantime, we’re working with Taiwan’s very strong LED supply chain to design and develop LED lighting products so that we can go to market.
Longer term, we’ll build our technologies with low cost volume manufacturing and with innovative product design using these technology capabilities to provide various solutions for this very exciting market.
Thank you and these are all my prepared comments. I believe we are open for questions now.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Yes, Natasha, could you please open this floor to questions? Thank you.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: (Operator instructions) Our first question comes from the line of Randy Abrams with Credit Suisse. Please proceed.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Yes, hi, good evening. Thanks for providing the additional detail on the additional CapEx split. Couple of follow-ups on that. On the NT$1.1 billion additional spending, I noticed 40-nanometer was absent from that. Does that imply that you’ve seen just more demand stay on 65 and you feel comfortable with 40, or is there anything to read into that? Second question on it, you talked this afternoon about capital intensity rising, do you have updated metrics on how much it’s costing to add 1,000 wafer per month capacity on 28-nanometer versus 40-nanometer and 65-nanometer?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Randy, yes, you’re asking about the CapEx spend on 40-nanometer. Actually when we build this 4.8 CapEx forecast, the biggest amount was to go the 40-nanometer, so with that amount still remain high. So in this update we did not change the number, because we see very strong demand from 65-nanometer that’s why we increased capital expenditure. Also for 28-nanometer and 20-nanometer because we’re a little bit very early scale, so we can side with R&D and also (inaudible) earlier. So that’s why the CapEx for NT$1.1 billion mainly attribute to 65-nanometer and 28-nanometer.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Dan Heyler with Bank of America-Merrill Lynch.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
Actually, I am sorry, Randy, I think Lora did not answer the second part of your question, which had to do with the higher capital intensity and you’re asking how much more capital intensive the 28-nanometer is I think that’s basically your question.
Well, I also said this afternoon and I would say it again, we pay very close attention to controlling the costs, and we call intrinsic costs. I used the term in my prepared comment. So that costs is not yet stabilized. In other words, we are still trying very diligently and in fact quite successfully to reduce the costs. So far, the capital investment in 28-nanometer is still only in the initial stage. And as I said we are using the initial stage to build up capacity for the risk production phase, but we’re also using this experience to lower the capital intensity of the 28-nanometer. So I cannot give you a number right now.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Well, Randy, if you are happy with the answer, can we go to Dan Heyler, now?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Thanks, Ho.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
I think I have the line. This is Dan Heyler. I think I’m live already. So a quick question on margins, guys. On the second quarter outlook, you’ve exceeded your revenue guidance by NT$104.9 billion or NT$105 billion versus the upper end of your guidance which was NT$102 billion, and then GP margin was just slightly below the upper end and OP margin was slightly above the upper end, so I guess that’s the first observation.
The second observation is on the guidance, despite your revenue growth of about 4% to 6%, you’re guiding effectively a flat to similar margin range of 48% to 50%. So if you could elaborate and help us understand the margin dynamics here despite the rising revenue?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
You’re asking about the margin about the second quarter and third quarter? On the second quarter, we have exceeded guidance in terms of revenue but the margin stayed at the high end of guidance not exceeding the guidance. We have observed two things in second quarter. Number one is, there were increases in room wafer price. So that had some negative impact on second quarter margins. Also the inventory valuation have effect on our second quarter because we view inventory for third quarter, so that is the reason. A similar reason on wafer pricing also goes through the third quarter, so that will have continue impact on the margin.
Also as Chairman commented this afternoon, because we are under very severe supply constraint, so we have made our most effort to satisfy our customer, to get more output in second quarter and third quarter. So we do not optimize the margin per se, but we do maximize the profitability.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Then a follow-up on that would be in relation to the utilization with the capacity growing at 7% sequentially and you’re guiding revenue of 4% to 6% assuming ASPs continue to be stable I guess. Will utilization decline at all in the third quarter and does that impact margins?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Well, third quarter utilization is too high, but it will be slightly lower than second quarter. So that does explain the margin stayed at the flat level as shown in our guidance.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: It is still high and it is still above 100%, but it’s a bit lower than the second quarter, I guess.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Finally, a little bit of a follow-up on the one that I had asked this afternoon on 40. Do you sense there may be an inflection point where you see, i.e. a certain level of contribution to sales or scale where we should see an inflection point on 40 or is it still linear progression?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I think that it’s more a linear progression, as you put it. So I expect that in the fourth quarter, it will be very close to the corporate average, and I really think that in the early part of next year it will exceed the corporate average.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Chou with Deutsche Bank. Please proceed.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Hi, good evening. Could you give us some color for outlook by applications for Q3?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Q3, relative to second quarter, we believe the Consumer and Communications segment in third quarter will increase, while Computer segment will decline slightly.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Is that possible that you can separate wireline and the wireless?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I am afraid that’s not appropriate because we are under a supply constraint situation, so the segment-by-segment actually is constrained by all capacity. So I don’t want to mislead you by providing the segment a color and you may use that to draw estimation of all customers’ business.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Okay, thank you. I will go back to the queue.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Randy Abrams with Credit Suisse. Please proceed.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for bringing me back in. I guess to follow-up on the capital intensity question, maybe less specific to 28-nanometer, but if you could give metrics, say, on how expensive it’s been to add additional capacity even this year or last year relative to prior cycles, if you could give a feel for how much capital intensity is rising?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Randy you’re asking the capital parity between other than 28-nanometer. I will give you one example. Take 65-nanometer and 40-nanometer as an example. In TSMC, we believe the 20-nanometer capital per k is roughly about 20% to 25% having that of 65-nanometer.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: As I said, we are trying to reduce the intrinsic cost from the equipment side and so we’re trying to control the capital intensity of 28-nanometers to at least similar to the 65-40 ratio, if not better.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Maybe two follow-ups, one is just on yields. I think you mentioned margin actually getting to the point it could be pretty close by year end. Its yields are actually also comparable. The second question I had was on the 2010 foundry growth, this afternoon where you said it was 40% for foundry industry. I think if we took TSMC in line with that and your 5% growth in third quarter, are you thinking about a fourth quarter, like a low single-digit type of decline for TSMC? Are you taking into consideration you think TSMC grows in line with foundries or could actually outgrow the foundry sector?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Randy, we do not give guidance on our fourth quarter.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Pelayo with HSBC. Please proceed.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Great. Thank you very much. Last earnings call, you talked about it was doubtful that you thought there was much double bookings going on, but you also said that demand was 30% to 40% above what you could supply. Now, here we are 90 days later and we’ve seen some incremental soft lines in PCs and mobile phones and even LCD area. So I guess I’m curious if you could talk a little bit about have you seen anything up at your level? I think you said that the computing segment was soft in 2Q and it would remain soft in 3Q. Is that broad based or one customer? I guess the gist of the question is, if you can go through the segments and talk about any incremental softness you may have also felt since last earning season.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Well, as you know, we don’t comment on that kind of details because we cannot review our customers’ business with us, and then as Lora has mentioned that both second quarter and third quarter we’re actually running at very tight capacity. While customers are actually being constrained by our capacity and so by giving out this detailed color we are actually mislead the market in terms of the true end market situation. So if you can forgive us, we will not answer that question.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Well, you did provide some color on your expectations for the segment in the third quarter. I think you said computing would remain relatively weak I think would decline quarter-on-quarter. What were your expectations for the other segment?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: All right, in fact, we said third quarter computer related applications will decline slightly. We did not say it remained relatively weak. In fact, second quarter our computer related applications actually went up by a low single digit, if you recall. The other two, I think communication probably will be better than consumer. Both are growing moderately probably in a range between mid-to-high single digit in the third quarter.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Then you talked also about a depreciation number. I think with the overall cash flow depreciation of about NT$89 billion this year. I guess two questions on that, the first one is, when you look at depreciation that’s in your cost of goods sold, give me some help on what that’ll be in the third and the fourth quarter? I know you don’t want to talk about 2011 capital spending, but at least we should have an idea for where do we think depreciation is going to be and what kind of run rate we are looking at for 2011 at this point. Can you help me out with those two things?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Steven, depreciation for this year, you are right, I did say that the total 2010 depreciation will be roughly NT$89 billion and we believe that second half depreciation will be higher than first half. You have seen our financial report. We have showed first quarter and second quarter numbers. So if you take the NT$89 billion and subtract those two numbers you can have idea of the second half numbers.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Steven, as I mentioned to you this afternoon, you can add about NT$1.5 billion from the second quarter level depreciation to the third quarter. Then since you have the full year depreciation, you can easily deduce the fourth quarter number.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Yes, I understand that. But the depreciation number and cost of goods sold is actually different than the cash flow depreciation, that NT$89 billion number that we are talking about, so I was just trying to get some specifics.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Yes, the difference is very little.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Then any thoughts on 2011? Are we going to continue to see that manufacturing depreciation go up and potentially govern gross margin?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Steven, 2011 depreciation still need to be worked out because since we don’t have the 2011 CapEx. Now with the high CapEx this year, I would say, I estimate that 2011 depreciation will be higher, about 18% higher than this year.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Heyler with Bank of America. Please proceed.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I thought it would be great if you could talk a little bit about the LED and the solar business. If possible, you’ve given more color and your investments are a lot more tangible now, when would we expect to see that start to contribute some revenue and we’d get a breakout on those businesses on a quarterly basis, when would that event begin?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I don’t think that it will contribute any significant revenue this year, and I believe it will begin to contribute revenue next year.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: When we began to see a quarterly breakout from TSMC financially?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I think it’s pretty hard to predict and I have already predicted next year, but I think it’s hard to predict which quarter.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Chou with Deutsche Bank. Please proceed.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Dr. Chang, just a follow up question for the foundry sector revenue growth, 40% year-on-year. Assuming TSMC revenue growth exceeds the foundry revenue growth by several single-digit points, so based on your Q3 guidance, is that fair to say that your Q4 revenue should be down single-digit? I know you cannot give the guidance for Q4, but if it’s based on your focus for total foundry revenue growth 40% growth for this year, is that fair to say that?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Firstly, we cannot guide fourth quarter, but when you look at the 40% foundry growth in terms of revenue, we mean in U.S. dollars and the number we reported on quarterly basis was actually NT dollars and NT has been appreciating this year would be more than 3%.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: So if we assume the 6% quarter-on-quarter growth for Q3 and around 3% to 4% NT dollar appreciation for this year, so is that fair to say that since our Q4 could be down single-digit quarter-on-quarter, because they really are affecting the NT dollar impact?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Michael, we really appreciate your persistence, but as Lora said we cannot give any guidance about fourth quarter at this point. You can make your own judgment.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Thank you. I have no further questions.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Satya Kumar with Credit Suisse. Please proceed.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Hi, can you hear me?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I just wanted a little bit more clarity on the supply growth. I appreciate the extra color that you gave today, but I’m just a little confused as to why the 300 millimeter capacity at the end of the year is not increasing by more, given the increase in CapEx that you talked about? I was wondering if you could provide a little bit more color on the capacity growth on 300-millimeter as we go into the early part of next year. I was wondering if that is being paid for in the CapEx this year.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Dr. Chang just talked this CapEx increase. He mentioned about increased growth to 28-nanometer, 20-nanometer and 65-nanometer and both of them are 12-inch. So actually, we add more CapEx on 12-inch.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I guess my question is why is that not showing up in the capacity number that you report at the end of Q4? It should be a higher number, but it’s only up a little bit over your previous guidance?

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Because if you look at year-over-year, we said from 13% to 14%, but if you look at quarter-over-quarter our third quarter capacity will be 7% more than second quarter, and will be another 3.5% more in fourth quarter. These two numbers was much higher than our previous guidance.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: I am sorry ask another question on this topic, but if I look the increase in 300-millimeter wafer start capacity that you are now giving for Q4 compared to what you had given earlier when your CapEx guidance was NT$4.8 billion, it’s about a 5,000 wafer start per month increase for Fab 12 and Fab 14 combined, whereas the increase in CapEx was one point more than NT$1 billion. So that sounds like a very high number and increase in CapEx compared to increase wafer start per month relative your prior guidance and that’s what I am trying to get a sense of.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext:
Let me just say this, when you look at the capacity plan, you see Fab 12, Fab 14 and you see some numbers, but what you do not see is the technology mix, and so not all the wafers are equal and so sometimes, we increase More of the Moore advanced technologies and sometimes we make certain switches. So this is very difficult for you just to look at these numbers into a conclusion, because there is indeed a dynamics of the product mix.
The second thing is even if we mention about the spending for the $1.1 billion, but some of the spending does not translates to capacity right away, so you cannot say all the spending are completely being reflected in the full quarter capacity that we have put out.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: That’s very helpful. I know you didn’t want to comment on 2011, but because we have the idea, if we thought that TSMC’s supply growth next year needs to be -

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: You’re right. We don’t want to comment on 2011.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: So I think we’ll wait. A couple more months and we can talk about 2011.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Okay. I will stop there then, thanks.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Operator, I think there are no more callers on the line. I think we can end this conference call.

headline: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttext: Before we conclude TSMC’s second quarter 2010 results webcast conference today, please be advised that the replay of the conference call will only be accessible to the TSMC’s Website at www.tsmc.com. Thank you all.
